utterances: Well, remember, China had been a huge market for American soybeans.
And they all but stopped buying last year in retaliation for Trump's tariffs.
They did start up buying soybeans again on a small scale last month during this sort of truce in the trade negotiations.
And in the Oval Office today, China's vice premier announced plans to really ramp up those soybean purchases.
Trump called that a welcome development.
(SOUNDBITE OF ARCHIVED RECORDING)

It's a sign of good faith for China to buy that much of our soybeans and other product that they've just committed to us prior to the signing of the deal - is something that makes us very proud to be dealing with them.
Again, that doesn't deal with the more difficult issues of intellectual property protection and technology transfer.
But it's certainly welcome news for a lot of Midwestern farmers who have been some of the big casualties caught in the crossfire of this trade war so far.
That's NPR's Scott Horsley speaking with us from the White House.
Thank you, Scott.
You're welcome.
And now here is NPR's Tony Cox with the gospel music great.

She may not have the name recognition that Nina Simone or Mahalia Jackson did in the United States, but for 20 years, gospel star Liz McComb has packed houses across Europe for a voice that is as raw as the blues and yet filled with the spirit.
The Cleveland-bred, Paris-based vocalist/pianist, like many African-American entertainers prior to desegregation, found a huge following overseas that continues today.
In 2001 she released her America debut CD, ""Fire."" And now Liz is back in the states with her latest CD, ""Soul, Peace & Love.
(Soundbite of song, ""Peacemakers"")
(Singing) And follow me.
(unintelligible) follow me (unintelligible) for it shall be called children of God.
(Singing) Blessed are the peacemakers.
(Singing) Peacemaker.
Children of God.
She joins me now from member station WCPN radio in Cleveland, Ohio.
Liz, bonjour, mademoiselle.
Bonjour, monsieur.
That's as much of my French as I can give you.
That's it.
That's the whole litany right there.
I know that you come from a musical family, and I know that your sound, as we said before, has been compared to Nina Simone and Mahalia Jackson.
How would you describe your own sound and your music?
Well, I have different shades of people, because I've listened to, as they say, Mahalia.
I grew up with that.
But I also listened to Billie Holiday, and I love Aretha Franklin, and I love Mel Torme.
I mean, I love jazz as well as gospel.
I think it's the same house, different rooms, to be honest with you.
(Soundbite of song ""God Made a Miracle"")
(Singing) You think you're hot (unintelligible).
No, no, no.
Now it has evolved, which music should do.
It's always been there.
(Soundbite of song ""God Made a Miracle"")
(Singing) God made a miracle for me.
(Singing) Oh, yes he did.
(Singing) God made a miracle for me.
(Singing) Oh, yes he did.
(Singing) He freed my soul, sent my spirit free.
God made a miracle for me.
You know, throughout history, Liz, many African-American artists have had to go to Europe to have their talents really recognized.
Why do you think you've found more success in Europe than you have so far here in the United States?
I think it gave me a period to be really creative.
And the Europeans don't keep up with - as much the Top 40.
I'm not knocking that.
But they are open to creativity.
They're very open.
I mean, you hear a lot of things before it ever becomes en vogue here.
You hear it way long ago there.
(Soundbite of song, ""Come Back Love"")
(Singing) Come back to me.
Soul, Peace & Love,"" which is the title of your new CD.
The producer, one of the producers here, and I we're talking about it.
And we both came up with the same description of it - eclectic.
And that's because…
I'm very eclectic.
Yeah.
I could tell, musically.
Very much so.
I mean you have ""Oh When The Saints"" as one of the traditional gospel songs on here.
And then you have a song like ""Come Back Lover,"" a sultry-sounding love song whose title, you know, most would not associate with gospel music.
What's the story in that song?
It is speaking about God's love for the church.
I mean, I speak right from the scriptures.
(Soundbite of song ""Come Back Love"")
(Singing) Before I stand the door and knock.
And I think the true essence of love is to be in communion with the Lord.
I mean, to surrender, so it's kind of like marriage.
You know, when I've had love in my life with a man, so I mean it's very simpler.
(Soundbite of song ""Come Back Love"")
(Singing) They (unintelligible) with your arms outstretched.
(unintelligible) don't care, taking me back.
Well, one of the songs that really caught my ear, it's called ""You Ain't Christian Enough.
(Soundbite of song ""You Ain't Christian Enough)
(Singing) So-called friend, somehow…
Why did you do that…
I was mocking folks.
Mocking is right.
